content.webTitle: José Mourinho loses special feeling for Chelsea and talks up Liverpool rivalry

fields.headline: José Mourinho loses special Chelsea feeling and talks up Liverpool rivalry
fields.bodyText: It is the fixture that releases an adrenaline rush at Manchester United according to José Mourinho, the game that carries extra significance for supporters and the rivalry of the Premier League. According to Mourinho that fixture is Liverpool. He has demoted Chelsea to the ranks of “any normal game”. The ramifications of Sunday’s result at Old Trafford ensure it is anything but. The United manager will find few dissenters to his argument that Chelsea’s visit has lost an edge as neither team is competing for the title, despite sitting second and fourth at the start of the weekend. On a personal level he claims the memories of delivering three Premier League titles to Stamford Bridge fade with every encounter against his former club. The importance of victory over a Champions League rival and competitor has not diminished, however, not when those supporters who Mourinho claims have Liverpool’s arrival on 10 March circled in their diaries are craving signs of genuine progress at Old Trafford. A six-point lead over Antonio Conte’s champions with 10 league games remaining would be an encouraging step. Being level on points following a third defeat in four league outings would shift the spotlight at United away from Paul Pogba and firmly on to the club’s direction under the Portuguese coach. Normal is not riding on Sunday’s fixture. Mourinho maintained: “It is any normal game and probably to play Liverpool in a couple of weeks’ time means more because for my club – and of course everyone knows the most important thing is not me – to play Liverpool really has a special meaning. That’s the way I have to look at things. I don’t have any bad feeling in relation to Chelsea to say: ‘Oh, I’m going to prove this and that against my former club.’ I’m not going to prove anything. In fact, every club I left – by my decision or by the board decision, and Chelsea was the only one [by the board] – I have very good feelings towards them. I’ve never played against Inter since I left but I’ve faced Porto, Real Madrid and Chelsea, the feeling is a good one. It’s not a special thing.” The United manager insists Liverpool’s visit will mean more because of history and not because Jürgen Klopp’s men pose a greater threat than a Chelsea team who, like United, have suffered two defeats in their last three league games and also drew the first leg of their Champions League last-16 tie. “No, it is still three points,” he said. “But the feeling for the fans, that little extra adrenaline, is not about Chelsea, it is more about Liverpool. I think Chelsea was almost winning against what just about everyone agrees is the best team in Europe in midweek. I don’t think Chelsea are in bad form at all.” Ander Herrera was instrumental in United’s 2-0 win in the corresponding fixture last season, scoring the second and man‑marking Eden Hazard to telling effect in what was Chelsea’s last league defeat before lifting the title. Herrera could be absent for up to six weeks with the hamstring injury he suffered at Sevilla in midweek but Mourinho claims he might not have repeated the tactic had the Spanish midfielder been available. “It was a special game in the sense that we were also trying to win the Europa League,” the manager explained. “We had lots of matches and lots of tired players. In that match I chose to rest some players. Ibrahimovic was so important to us so I kept him on the bench. With so many changes we had to go for a certain strategy where we felt that with the players available Ander’s job on Eden Hazard was important. He did an amazing job but these are different matches, conditions, circumstances, players. “In that match Eden Hazard was playing with Diego Costa as the No 9. In this match I don’t know what they will do, but in their last match against Barcelona Hazard was the most offensive player. With different circumstances I don’t think it’s the same situation that Ander had on him. Of course Hazard is a very important player for them but Willian is also an important player for them. They have other players who are very important but he [Hazard] is difficult to neutralise because of his individual qualities.” With Herrera sidelined and Pogba’s position not guaranteed – though Mourinho praised the France international’s professional reaction to being dropped against Sevilla – Scott McTominay may get another opportunity to showcase the potential that has left England and Scotland competing for his international services. The 21-year‑old was born in Lancaster but his father is Scottish and the midfielder has yet to confirm his allegiance. Mourinho said: “I’ve given him my advice but I think the advice of his parents is more important. His own heart is more important than my advice, because mine is purely from a career point of view. More important than his career is his feeling, his family’s feeling and also the overall situation with him. “He’s going to have a very good career independent of his international choice – if he has the choice, because maybe Scotland or England don’t want to select him, which is also possible. The most important thing is for him to feel good with himself.” Mourinho was asked whether he would say what he advised. “No,” was the reply.
